name: Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whirlwind Heist
description: A 15 minute heist game by Crows Crows Crows & Directed by William Pugh (The Stanley Parable). Slip into the soft-soled shoes of the mastermind responsible for the greatest heist- oh god I can’t do this any more, i’m joining the strike. good luck writing the steam description.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP SP2 or higher Processor: 1.80GHz Processor Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: Video card with 512MB of VRAM Storage: 1 GB available space

reviews.review_text: Exciting heist game! There are multiple approaches to entering the mansion, in my playthrough I chose the roof. Taking down the snipers with the tranquilizer gun was fun, at least until the chimney I was climbing collapsed. Not sure if that was scripted or a trap? It brought me right to a garden level where there was a cool chase sequence involving a tiger. After that it was back in the mansion and on to the vault. The patrolling guards' narrative was amusing with a couple of in-jokes, although their AI needs a little work. I crouched right by one and they didn't see me. The game has good weather effects though, which actually distracted them so I could get to the elevator leading down. Some weird dialogue in the elevator made me think I was missing something, but anyway after that it was straight to the vault and the emerald. The game seemed to glitch a little on picking up the emerald but I guess that's why it's free... all in all a good game experience!  The good: -thrilling stealth gameplay -exciting chase sequence -funny narrative  The bad: -long load times -weird muffled dialogue throughout -some audio and visual glitches making me think the game crashed where it didn't.

Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whirlwind Heist is a game made by the guy who brought us The Stanley Parable.   To explain the plot it would ruin the game, so I will keep it simple. You walk around the game while the voice guides you around and forces you to do stuff (I know that this is a horrible description, but I can't summarize it any better)  The game unlike The Stanley Parable only has one ending so apart from the one playthrough there is no replay value.  The game is incredibly funny and one of the funniest games I've played to date. I loved every moment of it.   There is not much to say about this game other than play it. Anything I say can spoil the entire experience so I'm gonna end the review right here. Just play it.  Final Rating: 8/10 - Play It  If you liked this review please consider giving it a thumbs up and if you disliked post in the comments on what you disliked about the review.  For more reviews follow Snort's Review curator page  here  - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whirlwind Heist is a unique heist game where the player's goal is to steal a prized emerald from a mad scientist's mansion undetected.  Pros: Unique stealth mechanics Funny guard dialoge (think Thief Gold style) Very atmospheric Fine balance between humor and 'seriousness'  Cons: Tiger attacks can get a bit annoying Guard AI is finicky at times  Tips and advice: Guards can often be picked off one by one, don't take them on all at once! If you must fire your weapon, do so during lightning strikes to conceal your shot.
It's like a 20 minute Stanley's Parable. I genually laughed and had a blast and would totally pay for a longer version. Go get it - it's free! 9/10

Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whirlwind Heist is an amazing short indie game. It takes you on a small adventure, behind the scenes of a 'game'. As you would expect from a William Pugh directed game, it had a comical script, which accompanied the amazing atmosphere quite pleasantly. The achievements provide a bit more replayability, with challenges such as collecting all the pretzels or turning off all the lights.  If you enjoyed The Stanley Parable you'll definitely enjoy this game. It has the same concept as The Stanley Parable with it's comedic aspects and also it's creative scenery and story-line. A unique game with an amazing concept with the ability to play it for free. What's not to love about Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whirlwind Heist.  Overall, I had no regrets playing this insanely creative game and would gladly purchase the game or a sequel as the narration was just too hilarious. My time well spent with a humorously different ending!

The fact that the designer of The Stanley Parable directed this little game should give enough of a clue to what you should expect out of it.  It plays with your expectations from the get go, while simultaneously providing comedy. Your first time playing it, you'll likely unlock just the achievement for finishing the game. There's more content strewn around the game world if you look through all the nooks and crannies.  I really don't know what else to say about this without spoiling too much of it. Go download it, it's a fun 15 minutes (an hour for completionists).
I like these kinds of things. It's funny and worth 20 minutes of your time. Also its ♥♥♥♥ing free, just do it, will you?

[ENG / FR]  [ENG]  Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whirlwind Heist is the latest creation from The Stanley Parable developer. In order not to unveil its content, I will only sum the game up through some characteristics.  + Voice acting and sound ambience are very carefully made, like it was the case with The Stanley Parable + Leaves a good memory once finished + Steam cards and achievements extend its lifetime + Completely free  - Rather short (About twenty minutes) - Limited replay value  This game is recommended to everybody, even if you never tried The Stanley Parable before. The making of this little game has taken much more time that you will spend on it but it really deserves your attention, especially at this price.  ▬  [FR]  Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whirlwind Heist est la dernière création du développeur de The Stanley Parable. Afin de ne pas en dévoiler le contenu, je vais me contenter de donner que quelques caratéristiques le concernant.  + Doublage et ambiance sonore soignés, tout comme pour The Stanley Parable + Laisse un bon souvenir une fois terminé + Bénéficie de cartes et de succès Steam qui prolongent sa durée de vie + Entièrement gratuit  - Plutôt court (Une vingtaine de minutes) - Rejouabilité limitée  Ce jeu est recommandé à tou(te)s, que vous ayez joué à The Stanley Parable ou non.  La conception de ce petit jeu a dû demander bien plus de temps que vous n'y passerez, mais il mérite vraiment votre attention, surtout à ce prix.

Soo, should you waste your time on Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whirlwind Heist ? Well, apart from the bad title (which is intentional), its actually a good 15-30 minutes small and funny game. Its certainly got the comedy of Stanley Parable, and its even in the same genre as the Stanley Parable, which is a walking simulator adventure game. Its more like try yourself to see the beauty in it kinda game, soo there's not much that i can say except that its really funny and will makes you laugh out loud or at the very least, it could makes you smile a bit. If you really like the comedy though and haven't played the Stanley Parable, you should pick that up and laugh at every jokes that game throw at you.  The story, hmm.. If you see the description its a compelling game about heist... Wait a second.. a strike ?! There is something strange here... To know what is this game and why i recommending it to you even though its strange description, you got to try it yourself. ;)  Its a free game that will make you laugh out loud and at the very least, smile a bit. If you want more than that ?? I-i guess you are the reason why a lot of people in this game go on strike !

An exemplar production!  An immersive experience with terrific effects and suspense! The tiger! That escape sequence! I was on the edge of my SEAT!  I suppose if I had any minor quibbles, sometimes it became abundtantly obvious that I was not, in fact, commiting a heist in a mansion (the production team REALLY should get a handle on their crew; I heard whispering going on off stage more than once. Unprofessional. Likely overstaffed). I also didn't feel as if my choices had much impact on the overall experience (what if I didn't WANT to steal the emerald? Freedom and choice should be a priority).  But it hardly detracts from a solid, fulfilling experience that is sure to give every audience member an exciting story to tell once it ends.  5 stars!

I can definetley reccommend this game, especially since it's free.

Incredibly short game for what it is. Although Crows Crows Crows did a good job and you definately get that Stanley Parable vibe from it I was a little disappointed in what I got but grew to enjoy the game for what it was - on a single playthrough that is. Although I'll be giving it a good review there are aspects of this game potential players should be aware of to prevent possible frustration.  Achievements are broken.  You can only get one achievement at a time. Don't even think about trying to knock them all out the park at the same time because it won't work - and don't even think about opening Steam Overlay in game or there goes your chance of getting an achievement.  The reason for nearly 3 hours of gameplay was, play once; gets the 'Start the Game' achievement. Close the game and re-open, get the next achievement; close the game and re-open to get the next achievement and so on. This is what makes the game boring. You're playing the same game 6 times just to get all the achievements which isn't the best way around making a short game longer. Unless you're an Achievement Hunter, don't bother with this one.

Do you want to download this game? Yes. Yes you do. Why? Because: +The controls are tight, and volume doesn't start out too high meaning you won't have to turn it down. +Speaking of sound, the game's music is some of the best... ever, and completely nail the 'heist' theme. +The plot is easy to follow, but not too simplistic. It has a deeper meaning that you won't find in most other heist-games-that-are-definitely-heist-games. +Dr. Langeskov's voice acting is delicious to my ears. Would be a bit better as Morgan Freeman doe. +The 'Cursed Emerald' was... wait no, I won't spoil it. It has some downsides, though. Such as: -The grapple controls are a bit too much to take in. -The 'Cursed Emerald'... dammit, I can't spoil it. -Too many memes. -Very little replay value. -Some of the puzzles were a bit too cryptic for me to understand.  Overall 9/10 a very solid heist game that is about heisting and definitely has a tiger in it.

This game is very funny but I'd be lying if I said I found it as entertaining as The Stanley Parable. The most major reason for this is the fact the game is not at all what it advertises itself as. It pretends to be about a heist being performed on a mansion, so I went in thinking it was going to be a choice based game like The Stanley Parable, but instead of searching an office building for your missing colleagues you'd be stealing from a mansion. The trailer describes a lot of interesting scenarios such as incapacitating guards and secret passages. The mere addition of combat, other characters and stealth could have really added to The Stanley Parable's formula, but no. The game's story amounts to this: There's another player playing the game so you can't play it yourself, so the narrator decides to make you perform tasks around the studio to help the player currently playing to have a better experience. While you perform these actions there are a lot of jokes and Easter eggs to experience. These are what make me recommend this game, although they are slightly hurt by the lack of major decisions throughout the game. There are small things you can do to make minor changes to the dialogue, but nothing major like you could in The Stanley Parable and when interacting with the environment is the only gameplay in your game, being able to make major changes is a bit necessary. Graphically the game is on par with The Stanley Parable, meaning it's passable, but nothing special. Looking back, the trailer and screenshots are mostly from the studio and the description sort of eludes to the twist, so I probably should have worked it out. But everything else is so convincing. The achievements all seem to be ripped from a heist game and the trailer I just mentioned ends with a close up of a vault that never shows up in game. Even after the game itself tries to make you think you're going to play a heist game. The menu is a getaway vehicle, the loading screen is full of tips for the heist, while you're going around the studio the narrator talks about things in the game. I kept thinking that the studio bit was just a fun little diversion before the main game, or maybe it was trying to show you what to expect when you actually perform the mission. But no, when you go through the doors at the end and you get the achievement for starting the heist, another player comes along and releases the tiger, killing you before the game really begins. I know the game's trying to play a joke, making you think you're playing heist game before pulling the rug from under you, but it feels really cheap.  Verdict: Good, but not that good.

While there are some frustrating things here and there, like the OP levels and the badshit crazy AI the gaurds have, though this is a must-buy for any good stealth fan, and even if you arent this game might hook you it's so good! 10/10!!!!    Happy? Good!           Okay, okay, i know you arent, and for a 15-35 minute game, none of those things ive mentioned inhabit this game, heh, not even close, what what it does have, is the charmy charm-charm of the Stanley-Parable, it's so clever it almost hurts.  Here's the rundown, you are ABOUT to play the totally fantastical game i mentioned before, but becuase another player is still occupant IN the game, you have to wait, and the incredible voice actor leads you away from the waiting, to help out with the supposed game the 'other player' is playing becuase all of the workers have quit or something idk. You go do some stuff, its free so no reason to spoil it, but yes, you do come across the tiger, but not a boss fight. Just sayin. The totall game is brillinant, and have a very 'indistructible' metal cover that lures the player in to something cool, at the end, you do eventually get to go to the room to play the game, but the game sadly exits to the title screen. The reason i am writing this part of the review is to tell confused players that there is kind of an inside-joke in the steam community to keep this game as it's advertised. Let's keep the ball rolling, starting with you!  9/10

When I first played this game, I honestly thought I was going to end up attempting to pull off a heist, since I didn't really know anything about the game, even though the description (or lack thereof) should've been a clue. So, when I started seeing papers with guard patrol patterns and the like, I picked them up and tried to memorize them. I even took some of the hints during the loading screen seriously. I think it was the room with the tiger (yes, I know, that's pretty late to realize something like this) that I realized how wrong I was and an already enjoyable game became even better.  I enjoyed everything about this game, from the voice acting, to Simon Amstell's stellar performance, and even how inept my character was, especially when it came to answering a phone. It's only fifteen minutes long and it's free, so you aren't losing out on anything by trying it out.  Just don't tap the cage. Or do. I don't care, it's your hand

After the second or third time (besides achievements) I wanted to uninstall. Game mechanics are great, you can pick papers, spin coffee cups, pick up/hand up phones, and all that great stuff. If the game were longer, I would really appreciate the game mechanics, but with a 15 minute game it was a waste. SPOILERS AHEAD, READ AT RISK OF GAME: If you actually did the Heist, then I would have said YES! hands down best game. But because of there not being an actual heist, I lost interest in the game very quickly. The game mechanics were a somewhat waste, but I still liked it the first time I played it, because I expected a heist but those hopes and dreams were crushed by some kid who likes flipping switches that let loose tigers. Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whielwind Heist is a game where you play as a master thief, in search of The Cursed Emerald.   The game is brilliantly designed; in fact, this may be one that could rival that of other stealth heist games, such as Payday or even Splinter Cell. With tons of variety when it comes to the heist itself, this game is a cut above the rest and is something everyone should play.   Plus, it's free!   How could you beat that?

So, this will be a spoiler-free review.  What can I say about  Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald: A Whirlwind Heist ? I admit the ending took me off-guard and I smiled, but with knowing  The Stanley Parable  already, it didn't have such an impact on me. While the former made me laugh on each subsequent play (until I ran out of endings, that is), this is an one-time gem. Once you play to the end, the magic is gone.  Also, apparently I'm one of these 49% of players, to whom the achievements aren't working.  On the plus side, this game is free to play, so you're not loosing anything in trying, so once you have need to pass the time, get this one and play.

This game, for how short it is, is incredible. The atmosphere is amazing. The lighting (the storm was really cool), the swelling music, the colors and the art style...it was all SO perfect. Really made me want to see more!  The controls were easy to master, though the AI pathing is a bit wiggly at times. The tiger was a nice surprise -- any by nice, I mean terrifying. I'll never forget that chase sequence. The lasers got me a few times, but after a couple of runs it was easy to see the path I needed to take.  Some things felt a little OP though. This game, (going to refer to it as that due to the lengthy title) is amazing. You wouldn't believe it to be possible for a small Indie Dev to pull off such an immersive action-packed stealth game. As said by others the AI of the guards is spectacular, meaning that you have to co-ordinate well-planned attacks to get into the building unnoticed. The fact that all of this is on top of a mountain with breath-taking views makes the game visually-stunning and emmersive. The real-time combat system and the open world destructable environment makes this nothing short of a skyrim with guns, in the future mixed with a James Bond film, with one scary tiger.

Kids, let me tell you a story: Once upon a time, there was a 26 year old guy called Tony. Tony had been playing games since the early days of the PS1. The first game he ever played was Spyro. He loved it, and from there on, he became a made gamer, going from the PS1 to the PS2, to the PS3 to the PC. He started with the rig he is currently writing this review on: a Toshiba Sattelite. Call him a noob, a ♥♥♥♥♥, a ♥♥♥♥♥♥, a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, a ♥♥♥♥ dub, a ♥♥♥♥♥♥, a dumbass, an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, a ♥♥♥♥♥ucker, a ball-licker, WHATEVER. He prefers to call himself an inovator. He beat Sleeping Dogs, Fallout 3, Fallout: New Vegas, Westerado, and is yet to buy and play the hell out of Worms Clan Wars. Tony always had a softspot for F2P games, for them being, well...free, and because that allowed him to find good and stable games that he could enjoy, run, and play on an otherwise ♥♥♥♥♥♥ machine. One day, whilst browsing the 'Free Games' section on Steam, he found a game that was being praised like God on both the Steam forums and on YouTube: 'Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, And The Terribly Cursed Emerald: a Whirlwind Heist' He played once for about 20 minutes, because that is actually howlong the game takes to beat, and he imagined there were other endings other than the one he got, therefore the Achievements he didn´t get and the descriptions for said achievements. Steal an orange from the orangery? I didn't even find an orangery! And I beat the damn thing! Either way, thanks for reading my LOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOONG review 'till the end and please, install this game, it's from the creator of the Stanley Parable for God's sake!
